metadata.guideline_reference: KNGF Guideline on Neck Pain (2016), Quebec Task Force WAD Classification

patient_profile.name: Sophie van Dijk
patient_profile.occupation: Graphic designer - works at computer 8 hours/day
patient_profile.referral_reason: Neck pain and headaches following motor vehicle accident 3 weeks ago

injury_mechanism.description: Patient was stationary at traffic light, struck from behind by another vehicle at approximately 30 km/h
injury_mechanism.position_at_impact: Seatbelt on, head turned slightly to right checking mirror
injury_mechanism.immediate_symptoms: Immediate neck pain and stiffness, headache developed within hours
injury_mechanism.emergency_care: Attended ED, cervical spine x-ray negative for fracture, discharged with paracetamol
injury_mechanism.insurance_claim: In process with other driver's insurance

presenting_complaint.chief_complaint: Constant neck pain and stiffness with daily headaches
presenting_complaint.pain_location: Bilateral posterior neck, more right than left, radiating to right shoulder and upper trapezius
presenting_complaint.headache_location: Starts at base of skull, radiates to right temple
aggravating_factors: Driving (afraid to drive but has tried once)
presenting_complaint.24_hour_pattern: Morning stiffness (7/10) improves with movement, worsens through workday, headaches worst by evening

current_status_3_weeks_post_injury.patient_narrative: The accident really shook me up. Even though the doctors said nothing is broken, my neck has never felt like this. I can barely work at my computer - after 30 minutes I have to stop. I'm terrified of driving now. My partner has to do all the driving and I feel so dependent. I've had to stop yoga and running. I'm worried this is permanent - what if I can never work properly again? I keep thinking about the accident and can't sleep well. My daughter wants me to pick her up but it hurts too much.

psychological_status.sleep_quality: Poor - difficulty falling asleep, nightmares about accident
psychological_status.intrusive_thoughts: Yes - replays accident, hypervigilant in cars

red_flags_assessed.status: Negative - no gait disturbance, no bilateral symptoms
Negative - no 5 D's (dizziness is positional, not sustained)
Negative - no fever, no night sweats
Negative - no weight loss, no history of cancer
Negative - no prolonged morning stiffness, no multi-joint involvement

red_flag_screening.clinical_reasoning_note: No red flags identified. Symptoms are consistent with WAD Grade II. Dizziness is mild and positional - monitor but not concerning for VAI.

psychosocial_factors_identified.evidence: Fears permanent damage, 'what if I can never work'
Intrusive thoughts, nightmares, avoids driving (accident reminder)
None - seems willing to engage in active treatment
Insurance claim in process - monitor as potential barrier

yellow_flags_assessment.prognostic_implications: Multiple yellow flags present predict slower recovery. Addressing psychological factors is essential for good outcome.
yellow_flags_assessment.clinical_note: Post-traumatic stress symptoms and driving avoidance suggest possible PTSD features. May need psychology referral if not improving.

wad_classification.criteria: Neck complaint with musculoskeletal signs (decreased ROM, point tenderness)
wad_classification.rationale: No neurological signs (would be Grade III), no fracture/dislocation (would be Grade IV), more than just pain/stiffness (would be Grade I)

other_grades.grade_0: No neck complaints, no physical signs
other_grades.grade_1: Neck pain, stiffness or tenderness only, no physical signs
other_grades.grade_3: Neck complaint + neurological signs (weakness, sensory deficit, reflex changes)

observation.posture: Forward head position, elevated right shoulder, guarded cervical posture

active_rom_cervical.pattern: Most limited into right rotation and extension - direction of impact

neurological_screening.clinical_note: No neurological involvement - confirms WAD Grade II

vertebral_artery_screening.sustained_rotation_test: Negative - no symptoms with 30 sec hold each direction
vertebral_artery_screening.clinical_note: Dizziness with quick movements is likely cervicogenic, not vascular

palpation.muscle_tone: Increased tone/guarding in cervical paraspinals and upper trapezius
palpation.trigger_points: Active trigger point right upper trapezius referring to head

craniocervical_flexion_test.result: Unable to hold 24mmHg, poor activation of deep neck flexors
craniocervical_flexion_test.interpretation: Deep neck flexor weakness/inhibition - common in WAD

joint_position_error.result: Increased error relocating to neutral (>4.5 degrees)

smooth_pursuit_neck_torsion_test.result: Mild increase in corrective saccades with trunk rotation

cervicogenic_headache_criteria.clinical_note: Meets criteria for cervicogenic headache secondary to WAD

impact_of_events_scale.interpretation: Moderate PTSD symptom level (>33 suggests probable PTSD)

personal_factors.previous_coping: Good - was active and healthy before accident
personal_factors.motivation: High - wants to return to normal life

prognostic_factors.prognosis_prediction: Mixed prognosis. Physical presentation is moderate (WAD II), but significant psychological factors predict slower recovery. Early addressing of fear-avoidance and possible PTSD is critical.
prognostic_factors.recovery_timeline: Most WAD II recovers within 3 months, but with these yellow flags, extended recovery (6+ months) possible if psychological factors not addressed.

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to work at computer for >30 minutes due to neck pain and headache
problems.participation_impact: Struggling to maintain work productivity, at risk of sick leave

problems.activity_limitation: Unable/unwilling to drive due to fear and pain with head rotation
problems.participation_impact: Dependent on partner for all transport, unable to take daughter to activities

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to pick up and hold 3-year-old daughter
underlying_impairments: Neck pain aggravated by upper limb loading
Belief that exercise will cause harm
problems.participation_impact: Loss of fitness, stress relief, social connection from yoga

long_term_goal.goal: Full return to work duties, independent driving, resumed yoga and running, and caring for daughter without limitation

short_term_goals.goal: Work at computer for 60 minutes with breaks, pain ≤4/10, using posture and break strategies
Complete a short car journey as passenger without significant anxiety (self-rated 4/10 or less)
Pick up daughter for brief periods (1-2 minutes) with pain ≤4/10
Resume gentle yoga class (modified positions as needed)
Resume running - start with 15 minutes walk/jog
NDI improved from 52% to <35% (severe to moderate)

intervention_plan.treatment_approach: Multimodal approach per KNGF guideline: education, exercise, manual therapy as adjunct, and addressing psychological factors. Active approach emphasized.
key_messages_for_patient: Your neck is not damaged - x-rays were clear
WAD is very common and most people recover fully
Tissues heal in 6-12 weeks - your neck is getting stronger
Hurt does not equal harm - movement is safe and helpful
Avoiding activity will delay recovery, not protect you
Your anxiety about driving is understandable - we'll address it gradually

interventions.intervention: Explanation of WAD, prognosis, pain neuroscience
content: What happened to your neck (soft tissue injury, not damage)
Why pain persists beyond tissue healing
Role of anxiety, stress, sleep in pain

interventions.intervention: Active ROM, deep neck flexor training, general strengthening
exercises: Active cervical ROM in all directions (hourly)
Craniocervical flexion training (deep neck flexor activation)

interventions.approach: Adjunct to exercise, not standalone treatment
interventions.caution: Avoid high-velocity thrust in acute WAD
interventions.evidence: Moderate - as part of multimodal approach

progression: 3. Short ride as passenger in quiet area
interventions.rationale: Avoidance maintains fear. Graded exposure builds confidence.

interventions.intervention: Progressive return to yoga and running
yoga_progression: Modified yoga poses (avoid prolonged neck positions initially)
interventions.evidence: Strong for graded activity in WAD

interventions.referral_threshold: If PTSD symptoms not improving by week 4, or worsening at any time, refer to psychologist

plan_of_care.frequency: 2x/week for 4 weeks, then 1x/week for 4 weeks, then 2-weekly

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Focusing on cervical impairments while ignoring significant psychological factors
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: You've identified cervical ROM and strength deficits. What psychological factors did you identify? How might these affect recovery if not addressed?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Advising rest or collar use beyond acute phase
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: What does the evidence say about collars and rest for WAD? What are the risks of prolonged immobilization?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Excessive passive treatment, avoiding active approaches
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: You've scheduled 3 manual therapy sessions per week. What is the evidence for active vs passive treatment in WAD? What balance would you recommend?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Ignoring the driving avoidance as 'she'll drive when she's ready'
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient is completely avoiding driving. What happens to fears when we avoid the feared situation? How might you address this?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Not recognizing post-traumatic stress features and need for referral
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient has nightmares, intrusive thoughts about the accident, and avoidance behaviors. What might these indicate? When would you consider referral?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Not considering how litigation might affect recovery
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient has an insurance claim in process. How might this affect recovery? How would you address this in treatment?

step_1_data_collection: What WAD grade is this patient? What are the criteria?
What red flags did you screen for? Were any concerning?
What yellow flags did you identify? Why are these important for prognosis?
What do the high NDI and TSK scores tell you?
What features suggest possible PTSD? Why is this relevant?
step_2_problem_statements: You've listed 'reduced cervical ROM' as a problem. Is this an impairment or activity limitation?
How does the driving avoidance connect to the PTSD symptoms?
What is the relationship between her catastrophizing and her activity limitations?
step_3_goal_setting: Your goal is 'reduce pain.' How would you make this more functional and SMART?
The patient wants to 'get back to normal' - how do you translate this into measurable goals?
Is driving in 4 weeks a realistic goal given her current avoidance?
step_4_intervention_selection: Why have you chosen a multimodal approach?
How much of treatment should be active vs passive?
How will you address the driving phobia?
When would you refer to a psychologist?
step_7_reevaluation: What outcome measures will you reassess?
How will you know if the psychological factors are improving?
If she's not progressing at week 4, what would you consider?
